verses.text: Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard of all that God had done for Moses and for Israel his people, how the LORD had brought Israel out of Egypt.
verses.comment: Verse closely follows standard Masoretic Text ordering. 'LORD' is used for YHWH.

verses.text: Now Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, had taken Zipporah, Moses’ wife, after he had sent her away,
verses.comment: 'Sent her away' or 'sent back'; possible informal divorce or simply returning home.

verses.text: along with her two sons. The name of one was Gershom, for Moses said, “I have been a sojourner in a foreign land,”
verses.comment: Name explanation preserved; 'sojourner' is literal rendering.

verses.text: and the name of the other, Eliezer, for he said, 'The God of my father was my help, and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh.'
verses.comment: Name 'Eliezer' means 'God is my help'.

verses.text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, came with his sons and his wife to Moses in the wilderness, where he was encamped at the mountain of God.
verses.comment: 'Mountain of God' refers to Sinai/Horeb.

verses.text: He sent word to Moses, 'I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you with your wife and her two sons with her.'
verses.comment: Direct speech as in the original.

verses.text: Moses went out to meet his father-in-law. He bowed down and kissed him. They asked each other about their well-being and went into the tent.
verses.comment: 'Kissed him' is customary greeting; 'peace' = well-being.

verses.text: Then Moses told his father-in-law all that the LORD had done to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, all the hardship that had come upon them on the journey, and how the LORD had delivered them.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew word order closely.

verses.text: Jethro rejoiced for all the good that the LORD had done to Israel, in rescuing them from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.comment: 'Hand' is a Semitic expression indicating power; kept literal.

verses.text: Jethro said, 'Blessed be the LORD, who has delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians and out of the hand of Pharaoh, and has delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians.'
verses.comment: Blessing formula matches Hebrew.

verses.text: Now I know that the LORD is greater than all the gods, because in the thing in which they dealt arrogantly, he was above them.'
verses.comment: 'Dealt arrogantly' parallels Hebrew root; some translations use 'acted proudly against.'

verses.text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices to God. Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat bread with Moses’ father-in-law before God.
verses.comment: 'Eat bread' is a Semitic expression for sharing a meal.

verses.text: On the next day, Moses sat to judge the people, and the people stood around Moses from morning until evening.
verses.comment: 'Sat to judge'—literal; Moses acted as judge.

verses.text: When Moses’ father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he said, 'What is this that you are doing for the people? Why do you sit alone, and all the people stand around you from morning until evening?'
verses.comment: Direct speech, Hebraic questioning preserved.

verses.text: Moses said to his father-in-law, 'Because the people come to me to inquire of God.'
verses.comment: 'Inquire of God'—as in the original.

verses.text: 'When they have a matter, they come to me and I judge between a man and his neighbor, and I make them know the statutes of God and his laws.'
verses.comment: Maintains roles of Moses as both judge and teacher.

verses.text: Moses’ father-in-law said to him, 'What you are doing is not good.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Hebrew negative assessment.

verses.text: 'You will surely wear yourself out, both you and these people with you, for the task is too heavy for you. You are not able to do it alone.'
verses.comment: 'Wear yourself out'—preserved idiom.

verses.text: 'Now listen to me; I will give you counsel, and God be with you. You represent the people before God and bring their cases to God.'
verses.comment: 'God be with you' is a literal blessing/benediction.

verses.text: 'You must teach them the statutes and the laws, and show them the way in which they must walk and the work they must do.'
verses.comment: 'The way...the work'—preserved from Hebrew structure.

verses.text: 'But you shall select from all the people able men, who fear God, men of truth, hating unjust gain, and place such over them as leaders of thousands, leaders of hundreds, leaders of fifties, and leaders of tens.'
verses.comment: 'Able men'—rendered as 'men'; pronouns not altered for inclusivity.

verses.text: 'Let them judge the people at all times. Every great matter they shall bring to you, but every small matter they shall judge themselves. It will be easier for you, and they will bear the burden with you.'
verses.comment: 'Bear the burden'—literal idiom.

verses.text: 'If you do this, and God so commands you, then you will be able to endure, and all these people also will go to their place in peace.'
verses.comment: 'Their place'—likely refers to their tents/home.

verses.text: So Moses listened to the voice of his father-in-law and did all that he had said.
verses.comment: 'Voice' is idiomatic for 'advice.'

verses.text: Moses chose able men out of all Israel and made them heads over the people: leaders of thousands, leaders of hundreds, leaders of fifties, and leaders of tens.
verses.comment: Follows earlier suggestion, keeping word order close to Hebrew.

verses.text: They judged the people at all times. The difficult matters they brought to Moses, but every small matter they judged themselves.
verses.comment: Matches the summary structure of the original text.

verses.text: Then Moses let his father-in-law depart, and he went his way to his own land.
verses.comment: 'Depart' is literal. Jethro likely returns to Midian.
